titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:15.Major Roberdeau, and Genl. Macomb here, with an old Black Letter leaf of a manuscript; found at Detroit. George went to Rockville— Miss Hopkinson passed the day at Mrs Kerr’s— At the Office— Mr Thompson Secy of the Navy—doubts whether Captain Wilkinson should be tried by a Court Martial— Papers from Spanish Minister against him. P.U.S. at the Office. Land Commissioners for East-Florida to be appointed. Agent to be sent to Cuba, and Porto-Rico. Gadsden otherwise employed. Draft to Canning sent to P.U.S.— Mrs. Adams and Mary Hellen, Evening at Mr Frye’s— I am still spell-bound in the assortment of public Documents. Morning and Evening engaged upon it— Letter to G. B. English. A. B. Lindsley again at the Office for a Clerkship.

2. V:15. At the Office—a Captain B. Turner, came, a claim for having brought home 98 Seamen, prisoners from Jamaica, during the late War— Cabinet Meeting—full— Agent to Cuba— Calhoun for a War to prevent G.B. from taking Cuba—if the Islanders are united against it— East-Florida Land-claim Comissioners— Floyd of Ohio Blair of Kentucky and A. Hamilton.— Cuba question largely discussed— Winder— T. Randall— Miss Hopkinson passed the day at Georgetown— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen. Eve at Mr Frye’s.

3. V:15. Letter from Johnson Hellen— George has fallen from his horse, and broke his arm— Call at the Office. Went to Rockville with Mrs Adams, Dr Huntt, and Elizabeth Phillips— Found George at the Washington Hotel, in bed with the bone at the joint of the elbow broken; not much pain; some fever attended by a Dr Wilson— Saw there Mr B. Forrest, J. Cooke, and Archer Lee—Johnson Hellen, himself quite unwell— Mrs Adams and Elizabeth remain at Rockville. Dr Huntt and I returned in the Evening to Washington.

4. VI.Mr Brent, and Mrs Frye, and T. Cook called to enquire concerning George— Brumley the collector for taxes. G. B. English for his business. At the Office; Major Roberdeau with his undecyphered manuscript. We compared it with some of the fac-similes of Old Acts of Parliament, in the Statutes of the Realm, which it strongly resembles— I despatched English, with a Letter of authority, a Passport and verbal instructions. Mr Maury the accounting Clerk of the Department is ill with the gout. L. Smith does his business and through him I furnished English without using his name. Captain Randall was twice at the Office— Agrees to go to Porto-Rico; explained to him the object of sending him, and discussed the terms— Barryman’s embarassments— How to relieve him? N. Biddle, President of U.S. Bank here about a debt of the Bank of Columbia to the Bank U.S. Letter from R. King— At P.U.S.Calhoun there— Judge of Supreme Court U.S— Kent, Spencer, Sanford— C. P. Van Ness— Van Buren. P.U.S. decided against the last— Miss Hopkinson passed the day, at Genl. Van Ness’s— Evening Miss Kerr, and Major Dix, and afterwards Mr Kerr here— My Evening wasted.

5. IV:45.D. Brent here—to go into the Country— Letter from Mrs Adams: George better, but still obliged to keep his bed. At the Office— N. Biddle, with J. M’Kim of Baltimore— They are to go to-morrow. Call at P.U.S. he was at dinner, and I left the papers.— N. Biddle was here; above; this Evening— And Petry; and Miss Kerr— Stultus labor ineptiarum—

6. V.Miss Hopkinson left us this Morning at 6. to return with Mr Biddle to Philadelphia— I went with Mary Hellen to Rockville; where we dined and returned and Eve— Read Ivanhoe on the road— Dr Huntt also went on horseback. George better, but only this day first could have his arm bent— Recovers slowly, and still has fever— Dr Wilson attends him— Evening read the day’s Mail, and was indexing papers.

7. VI. Preparing Draft of Instructions for H. Nelson— At the Office. Stackelberg brought king of Sweden’s speech to the Diet—29. Jany— Captain Randall. Not yet prepared for him. Letter to Rodman, Reynolds and Alvarez at St. Augustine—Despatch from H. Dearborn. At P.U.S— He has received a Letter from R. King, recommending Van Buren— Thompson has not yet definitively answered— H. Baldwin recommended by Lowrie— C. P. Van Ness by all Vermont— Wrote to R. King— Labor ineptiarum at Eve— Attempted writing; but could not. Sent for English who came to the Office— Directed him to send any Treaties that he may collect.

8. V:30.Dr. Thornton here. Stone’s parchments; and Jonathon Elliot’s. At the Office. P.U.S. there. His note directing me to write to H. Nelson, to go to Norfolk, and embark immediately in the Hornet, for Spain— To counteract Anduaga’s misrepresentations— Despatches from R. Rush. 20. Feby. and speculations— P.U.S. says G. W. Erving wishes to go to France, and to have some authority; as substitute in Mr Gallatin’s absence— Thinks he cannot be gratified— Mary Hellen dined at Mrs T. Munroe’s— I alone. Walk after dinner— Evening wasted upon the Casket. Carriage sent to Rockville.

9. VI.Mrs Adams returned from Rockville with George; who is yet weak, and feverish— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, Dr Huntt and Dr Thornton were here— I was occupied in preparing the Draft of H. Nelson’s Instructions. To Answer Anduaga’s invectives. At Secy of the Navy’s Office. Enquiring for several papers—Some of which were furnished me— To wait for others. Note from P.U.S. to write to A. Gallatin—advising him to stay in the Crisis— Evening worse than idle.

10. V:30. At the Office— A. Morris about his Accounts, with a new claim of allowance for a Secretary— Young Maury from Liverpool— G. W. Erving with a Letter for H. Nelson— Ogden Edwards from New-York.— Goes with the Letters of Introduction from R. King— Time absorbed— At Secy Navy’s, for papers, to make up Instructions for Nelson— Prize-master Commissions. Elton’s Letters— At P.U.S— Going to Loudoun to-morrow. Evening in confusion of labour and idleness.— Rice, to borrow money.

11. VI.G. W. Erving here. Going to France. My opinion of A. Morris— And also of general foreign politics— At the Office— A. Morris called and took his papers— B. Lear came, about the claims of Genl. Hull. Referred to the President, went this day to Loudoun— Voluminous despatches from J. Forsyth, Madrid— J. S. Wilcocks Mexico— W. Taylor Vera-Cruz, and Mullowny at Tangier, Morocco— Stone the Engraver, who has finished his fac-simile of the original Declaration of Independence. Dr Thornton, W. Elliott and Stone. Evening rather busier than the last— Force here this Morning— Says he was applied to, to print a Book for Jonn. Russell, which failed— De Krafft’s mistakes.

12. VI.George’s Birth-day. 22. morning engaged on the Draft of Instructions to H. Nelson, and Evening in assorting Papers for the Casket. Foxhall at the Office; going for England to-morrow. But I had not time to write by him— Search for Decrees of the District and Circuit Courts in the case of the Palmyra. Heavy Mail of despatches again this day—from Forsyth, Rush, Hughes at Stockholm, Mullowny at Tangier, and other Consuls— Prevost, Hogan, and J. M. Forbes— Note from Canning about the Colonial Intercourse: and Letter from Wirt about Cathcart.

13. VI. Met Clay and Wirt, as I was going this Morning to Church. Clay has come back from Philadelphia, on account of Coll. Morrison, who yet lies desparately ill— I spoke to Wirt about Cathcart. Heard Little A.M. Acts 10.34.35. “Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons:— But in every Nation he that feareth him, and worketh righteousness is accepted with him[”]—and in the afternoon Psalm 51.10. [“]Create in me a clean heart, Oh God: and renew a right Spirit within me.” Moral Discourses— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen were there in the Morning— Between the services, I visited Coll. Morrison, who is much emaciated since I saw him last, and will probably never recover. He expects the arrival of his wife to-morrow— I called at Mrs Wilson’s to see Captain Morris, the new Commissioner of the Navy, but he was out. Mr and Mrs de Bresson and Miss Louisa Thompson were here in the Evening.

14. VI.Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen both unwell with bilious complaints; and George’s arm continues in a state which gives me great concern. Mr.
Heman Allen the appointed Minister to Chile was here, and made enquiries respecting his mission— Inclines not to go before the Autumn. Recommends C. P. Van Ness, as judge of the Supreme Court U.S— Mr. Clay here— Smooth-tongued— European Politicks— Eustis Governor of Massachusetts Opinions of Otis— Member and vindicator of the Hartford Convention— At the Office; Mr Frye, for a Patentee— Mr Wirt, for Cathcart’s claims. Read him the Law, for Settlement of his accounts in full of all demands. Mr Calhoun, to recommend Consul at Antwerp— Draft of Commission, and beginning of Instructions to T. Randall— In the Evening Mr Baker; Minister of the Presbyterian Church here— Their distress— He intreated me to attend their Meeting next Monday, at 1/2 past 4 O’Clock. P.M— Assorting pamphlet Documents.

15. V:Mrs Adams very ill in the Night— Gassaway here this Morning. General Jessup, with Captain Jack F. Ross, applying for appointment as Marshal of Alabama—T. Livingston being dead— Ross brought a letter from Crowell— At the Office, Ross again, and Coxe of Georgetown, for his papers— Wrote Instructions for T. Randall— Evening heavy— George unwell.

16. V:30.H. Nelson here, bound for Spain, and H. Allen for Chile— Long Conversations with both. At the office. Maury returned after a fit of the gout— D. Brent absent— Consequently interrupted in the Draft of Instructions to H. Nelson. T. Randall came and is ready to go— Continued the draft of his Instructions and papers for him— In the Evening, Mr Thompson Secy of the Navy, Mrs Thompson and Louisa were here. Also Dr Thornton— Drowsy spell— Time lost.

17. VI.Baum, paper-maker here.— Left a card for Mr Allen at Brown’s Hotel— At the Franklin Insurance Office— Attended early at my Office for time to write; but in vain— Smith Cashier of U.S. Branch Bank, for sale of a Bill upon Amsterdam— Larned from Baltimore; about politics, and the Presidential Election. Comes in a very questionable shape; for buying up the Federal Republican Newspaper. I buy none— Major Ross came again with recommendations for the appointment of Marshal in Alabama. Major Hamilton, with Captain Jackson of the Revenue Cutter Louisiana. Brot a claim for 300 dollars paid Counsel in the case of the men taken in the Gallega— I could not pay it— But Jackson told me much upon the whole transaction. Spoke also of the Slaves captured by him in the General Ramirez.
Of the practices of the Marshal of Georgia, Morel, and of the horrible transactions of the Bulloch’s at Savannah; in the capture of the Swedish ship, Norburg— W. S. Smith brought a Letter from C. Root, applying for the appointment of Marshal in Alabama— Baum came about his paper, Stone about his parchment, and Mr G. Hay for contingent expences to his Office of Agent before the Slave indemnity Commission. I told him the Commission only could authorise them— He wanted a bursar, to lay the papers in, and a table to write upon— I told him they might be kept at the Office, and transmitted directly to the Comissioners. With all these visitors, I had an enormous Mail of despatches from A. Gallatin, Forsyth, Dearborn &c— I could not read them all— Judge Cranch was here this Evening— George unwell.

18. V:30. The Russian Minister Baron de Tuyll has arrived— Received a Note from him— Answered, appointing to-morrow to receive him at the Department.— At the Office; Captain Jackson came again, with a Document— I gave him Anduaga’s complaints against him and desired him to make an Affidavit of the facts, before a Magistrate, and to bring it to me— H. L. White the Florida Comissioner came to take leave. The Commission have adjourned, yesterday till July— Mr Wirt; came to enquire again about papers in Cathcart’s case— Also as to the Reports of former Commissions— Under the 7th. Article of the Treaty of 1794— I resumed the Draft of Instructions to H. Nelson, two days interrupted— Evening walk with Mrs. Adams— Petry here, above; and Mr Addington whom I did not see— Letter from J. W. Taylor.

19. VI: Much engaged in the Draft of Instructions to H. Nelson. At the Office. The Baron de Tuyll de Seraskirchen came alone— Expressed an anxiety to be presented as soon as possible to the President, and if he should not return soon from the Country, to go and ask for his Audience there. I had notice from the President that he would return to the City this day, and told the Baron it would not be necessary for him to go into the Country— Mr Addington and Mr Petry were here this Evening. I saw only the latter. Wrote to Judge C. Jackson— Captn. Jackson’s affidavit.

20. VI. Attended this Morning with Mrs Adams at the Presbyterian Church heard Mr Baker— Psalm 122.6.7.8.9. A soliciting discourse. Called at the President’s and saw him. He had a private Letter of 1. March from A. Gallatin— Urges his final recall from France— Speaks of his losses by the failure of his glass house, and of the Bank of Columbia. I sent
to the President afterwards the budget of despatches received during his absence— Returned the Baron de Tuyll’s visit— Told him the President would receive him at 1. O’Clock next Tuesday— Heard Little in the afternoon— Luke 9.28–36. Call afterwards and left a Card at Brown’s Hotel for Jos. Russell— He and W. Lee were here in the Eve. Walk after dinner with Mrs Adams.

21. VI.J. Bailey here— Mrs Hellen— Lieutt. Mayo with despatches from Commodore Stewart at Valparaiso— At the Office— Found Mr Nelson there— Afterwards came Mr H. Allen, with more enquiries— And Mr Canning finally came for a two hours Conversation— Slave-trade— Colonial Intercourse, right of search and European Politicks— Wants further explanations and answers to his last Notes. I told him I would answer them— Shewed me a Note from Chateaubriand of 23. January, and a reply from G. Canning of 28 January, being the sequel to the Correspondence he had shewn me before. The last takes in the most distinct and explicit manner the ground of denying the right of warning against Spain to change her internal Constitution— Mrs. A. Hellen with her son Walter here from Alexandria.

22. VI.Calhoun called at my house with recommendations of a Mr Armstrong as Marshal for Alabama— Bailey for the last sheet of the draft of Nelson’s Instructions— At one O’Clock I presented to the President the Baron de Tuyll, who delivered to him the Letter of Recall of Mr Poletica, and then his own Credential Letter as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from the Emperor of Russia— He made a short complimentary address to the President in French, which the President answered in our own language— The Letters of Recall and of Credence were in Russian, and the President delivered them to me unopened— As he withdrew the Baron asked me to fix a time for a Conference with him— I appointed Thursday at one O’Clock at the Office of the Department— I asked him also to send a list of the persons attached to his Legation, which he promised. I remained some time with the President; Mr Crawford came in— Conversation upon Mr Canning’s Notes, the Slave-trade and the right of Search— At the Office, Mr H Allen came, and I had a long conversation with him upon his Mission to Chile— He leaves the City to-morrow or the next day.— I called this Evening at Mr Thompson’s—Secy Navy. Left a Letter to my father, for De Bresson, who goes to-morrow, with his wife, for Boston— I asked Thompson if he had recommended any person to P.U.S. as Judge of the Supreme Court.— He said that immediately after the Death of Judge Livingston, Van Buren had
had written to him urging him to accept the appointment; which Letter he had answered assigning his reasons for declining, and closed his Letter by saying “Shall I mentioned your name to the President?” to which Van Buren had replied by a Letter giving at full length his reasons for accepting if the appointment should be offered him immediately; and authorising him to communicate that Letter to the President— I mentioned to Mr. Thompson that I had written to Mr King that he Thompson had not given his definitive answer to that President on the 7th. having so understood from the President himself— Thompson said that from delicacy he had not given his answer in terms of explicit refusal—though he had not meant the President should doubt what his intentions were— Thompson spoke also of Kent, Spencer, W. P. Van Ness and H. Baldwin— C. P. Van Ness and Skinner— Mr Hersant was married this Evening to Miss Cecilia Thompson— Mary Hellen was one of the Bride Maids— Mrs Hellen and her son Walter, returned to Alexandria. Johnson Hellen came from Rockville. And Mrs Adams received a Letter from her brother who is at Philadelphia.

23. V:30.Captain Ross here this Morning, with a new recommendation for the appointment of Marshal in Alabama— Note from P.U.S. respecting the Instructions to be given to T. Randall, of which he sent me back the drafts. Finished the Draft of General Instructions to H. Nelson— Took it to P.U.S. Thompson and Calhoun successively came in while I was there— Armstrong to be Marshal of Alabama— But a question is made whether his old Accts are settled— Small balance, about 200 dollars suspended— Question about the Instructions to Randall— The Demand of Restitution to be made by Gallagher— Captain of the Enterprize— P.U.S. directed me to write to Governor Duval of Florida, about the preservation of the timber— Sent him the Draft, and one of an answer to C. Price, about the claims on France. Walk with Mrs Adams after dinner. Joseph Russell here this Evening— Change of Weather— W. Lee sent me some volumes of Buffon, and one of a Dictionaire d’Histoire Naturelle; of which he wishes to dispose— At the Office this day he offered me his services— R. C. Anderson this morning at the Office.

24. VI. Great change of weather in the Night from Summer heat to frost. Attended Coll. Morrison’s funeral, at the Navy-yard burying ground. Mr Laurie gave a long Dissertation upon the certainty of Death— Mr Hawley added a few words only of the Episcopal Church Service— On returning home, I found T. B. Johnson had arrived— At the Office. H. Nelson— Going to-morrow for Richmond— Baron de Tuyll the Russian Minister came to the Conference at 1.
His proposals for a Negotiation upon the North-west Coast question. Confidential communication of two Instructions from Nesselrode to him, and of a Letter of 15. Feby from Count Lieven— The British Government has given Powers to Sir C. Bagot to treat concerning it— Tuyll asks that Powers and Instructions should be given to Middleton— I promised to report to P.U.S.— Received afterwards a note from Baron de Tuyll— C. A. Rodney came— Shewed me Letters of T. M’Kean and T. Jefferson about the Declaration of Independence— He goes in the Congress Frigate— Despatches from J. Forsyth of 3. March— Has taken leave of the King— On coming home to dinner, found Mrs Adams ill in bed. Seized suddenly with great violence— Ague and fever. Jos. Russell dined with us. Mr and Mrs Frye, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith here in the Evening— Mary Hellen’s chamber— She with Mrs Adams— Baron Tuyll introduced to me his Secretary of Legation Wallenstein.

25. V:15.Dr Thornton here— Spoke to him of Stone’s and M’Cardle’s parchments, and about fees, for giving copies of papers at the Patent Office. Told him an account of them must be rendered at the Treasury. W. Elliott afterwards here— Fees for copying to be accounted for to the Treasury— No record of the Patents kept, though required by Law— Price of the Parchment for Patents. Elliott now recommends applying for parchment to the manufacturer at Philadelphia— At the Office— Examined Abram’s Collection of Spanish Treaties. Ironside’s project for transmitting the Documents, to the States, by the Steam-boats— Second order from P.U.S. to commission Armstrong as Marshal of Alabama, and second order of suspension— At P.U.S. took to him the papers received from the Russian Minister— N.W. Coast question— Complaints by and against Prevost in Chile— Calhoun came in for a moment while I was there— Ross at the Office. Mrs Adams yet ill.

26. V:30.Ross here— Appointment of Marshal in Alabama to be postponed to hear from Armstrong— At Office— Met R. C. Anderson going there. He first wished to delay his departure; but on understanding the rules respecting the Commencement of the Salary, concluded upon proceeding immediately. Nelson is going to Richmond; will return through here, to embark in the Congress frigate at Newcastle— Rodney; going home to-morrow, to embark in the same frigate with Nelson— English Admiralty list. Order concerning the transportation of Bullion— Randall ready to go, but I have not his Instructions yet ready— Day thus absorbed and wasted by visitors— T. B. Johnson dined abroad— L. Rice here in the Evening— His proposals to purchase Metropolis Bank Stock— Taken for Consideration. Mrs Adams still confined all day to her bed— George with the tooth-ache. Letter to D. Cony— Returned to my Chamber.

27. V:15. Heard Mr Little A.M. with Johnson Hellen— Isaiah 29.16— “Shall the thing framed say of him that framed it, He had no Understanding?” a discourse upon the absurdity of questioning a first Cause— Lecture after the Service— Authenticity of many passages of the New Testament disputed— In a manner which I did not like. Jos. Russell came and took leave— Going to-morrow, for Norfolk or Baltimore, the next day— Call with Mr T. B. Johnson, and George at Mr Frye’s— Returned visits by Cards to Mr R. C. Anderson and Mr Bullitt at Peck’s Hotel; Georgetown to Mr Steadman at Mrs Wilson’s—and to Mr Wallenstein at Baron Tuyll’s. Johnson Hellen left us and returned to Rockville— Heard Little again P.M. Proverbs 16.17. [“]The highway of the upright is to depart from evil; he that keepeth his way, preserveth his Soul.” Mrs Adams came down to dinner. Finished this Evening, drowsily a Letter to Dr. D. Cony—

28. V:15.Mrs Adams who has applied a blister, kept her bed— Mr Bailey here this Morning. Letter from I. Munro of Baltimore— Frye with a Letter from Mr Randolph, in Alabama, soliciting the appointment of Marshal. I told him it was too late— Watkins, with Mr Leakin, Sheriff of Baltimore, and a Mr Martin; for a discharge from imprisonment of a man named Armstrong. Watkins shewed me a Letter from Girardin, about the Biography in the Port-Folio.— Shewed Watkins some of the Volumes of my despatches— Rice here again— To Call to-morrow— At the Office. Old Mr Gales of Raleigh, came with Seaton— Call at the President’s, who was not at home. Met Thompson Secy. Navy— Sent to Randall— Read all the Instructions to him. They are all to be given to him to-morrow, and he is to go off the next day. Dull Evening.

29. V:Rice here again— Agreed with him to transfer to Columbian College Metropolis Bank Stock— Took the Certificate there. W. D. Lewis here. The trial, of Harris’s action against him is postponed for at least two years. Upon an Affidavit of Harris claiming time— Harris is going himself to St. Petersburg— Lewis means to follow him— Asked a Letter to Middleton. At the Office— Lindsley came; wanting the Consulate of Cadix. P.U.S. came. Agrees to send Powers and Instructions to Middleton, about the N.W. Coast Negotiation. P.U.S. is going to Albemarle— Randall came— Furnished him all his papers and he is to go to-morrow. Dined at Mr Canning’s. CalhounThompson, Tuyll and others there about 20. Evening party at Coll. Thompson’s— Wedding— Cecilia Mrs Hersant— Dancing. Chess with Coll. Henderson— Mr and Mrs. W. S. Smith went with me.

30. V:W. D. Lewis here this morning; and left the City to return to Philadelphia— At the Office— Mr Canning— Two hours Conversation— Left a minute of several of his Notes to be answered— And spoke of the Slave-trade, of the Piracies— Of the Russian North-West Coast pretensions, and of the prospects of War in Europe. We had company to dine, Messrs.Addington, R. C. Anderson, Baker, D. Brent, Bullitt, Canning, G. Hay, Hersant, Baron Maltitz, Captn. Morris, Parish, Petry, Baron Stackelberg, Steadman, T. T. Tucker, Baron Tuyll, and Wallenstein— Messrs.D’Espinsville and Duclaud, Count Menou,Mr T. Randall, Jos. Russell and Wilmot, were invited, but absent or excused. Mrs Adams unwell, and not at table; nor any of the family but T. B. Johnson— Baron Tuyll asked an interview to-morrow fixed it at one.

Day— Rise between 5 and 6. Write till 9. Breakfast— Read newspapers and write again till one— Attend at the Office— Eastern Mail comes about two— Then two hours reading or more— Go to the President’s, with papers or for directions— Return to the Office— Between 5. and 6. home to dine— Evening write or read if possible— Bed about 11. H. Nelson’s Instructions and Draft of Answer to Salmon’s Note about R. W. Meade have occupied the Morning’s of the Month— The Current business of the Office, the remainder of the day— Little exercise.
